docs.snippet: In the old neighborhood in Montevideo they still remember him as the delivery boy from his parents' grocery store.   Enrique V. Iglesias's parents were Spanish immigrants who came to Uruguay from a Depression-ravaged Spain in 1934. His father was a...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the old neighborhood in Montevideo they still remember him as the delivery boy from his parents' grocery store. Enrique V. Iglesias's parents were Spanish immigrants who came to Uruguay from a Depression-ravaged Spain in 1934. His father was a coal miner in Asturias province in the northwest. The boy, who was born in the Asturias village of Aracedo, grew up to be Uruguay's Foreign Minister.

headline.main: Uruguay Official Exercises His Diplomatic Skills

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A new attempt to liberalize world trade is expected to be the most difficult such effort in the postwar period. There are a rising number of key players in the trading system, the United States Congress remains at odds with the President over...
docs.lead_paragraph: A new attempt to liberalize world trade is expected to be the most difficult such effort in the postwar period. There are a rising number of key players in the trading system, the United States Congress remains at odds with the President over protectionism and the easiest measures to foster more-balanced trade are already in place. The biggest stumbling block to continued progress, however, was removed here Saturday, when ministers from the signatory countries of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade set an agenda for the Uruguay round of trade talks, the eighth round since the agreement came into effect after World War II. The agreement on the agenda was reached after a weeklong meeting in a vacated hotel casino on a peninsula jutting into the wintry South Atlantic. In place of roulette wheels and slot machines were long rows of felt-covered tables where delegates from 74 nations argued over rules that should govern world trade into the 21st century.

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech today to the United Nations General Assembly, as recorded by The Associated Press:   Mr. President, Mr. Secretary General, honored guests and distinguished delegates, a short walk from this...
docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech today to the United Nations General Assembly, as recorded by The Associated Press: Mr. President, Mr. Secretary General, honored guests and distinguished delegates, a short walk from this chamber is the delegates' Meditation Room, a refuge from a world deafened by the noise of strife and violence. ''We want to bring back the idea of worship,'' Dag Hammarskjold once said about this room, ''devotion to something which is greater and higher than we are ourselves.'' It is just such devotion that gave birth to the United Nations: devotion to the dream of world peace and freedom, of human rights and democratic self-determination, of a time when, in those ancient words: ''And they shall beat their swords into plowshares. Nations shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war anymore.'' The United States remains committed to the U.N. For over 40 years, this organization has provided an international forum for harmonizing conflicting national interests and has made a significant contribution in such fields as peacekeeping, humanitarian assistance and eradicating disease.

docs.snippet: The Soviet Union has announced ambitious measures to decentralize and enhance its foreign trade, giving almost 100 ministries and enterprises the right to make deals directly with foreign partners.   Until now, trade has been conducted largely...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union has announced ambitious measures to decentralize and enhance its foreign trade, giving almost 100 ministries and enterprises the right to make deals directly with foreign partners. Until now, trade has been conducted largely through the Ministry of Foreign Trade and affiliated foreign organizations rather than with manufacturers or end users. That unwieldy process consumed considerable time and offered little incentive for Soviet enterprises to sell or buy abroad. Under the new measures, outlined in Tuesday's issue of the newspaper Sotsialisticheskaya Industriya, or Socialist Industry, more than 20 ministries and 70 major enterprises will have the right to operate directly with Western and developing countries and to maintain their own accounts in convertible currencies. The change takes effect Jan. 1.

byline.original: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: It took four years just to negotiate agreement for a new round of world trade negotiations. But 74 nations have now agreed to a broader sweep of bargaining than ever attempted before. The time is ripe. Last weekend's initiative in Punta del Este,...
docs.lead_paragraph: It took four years just to negotiate agreement for a new round of world trade negotiations. But 74 nations have now agreed to a broader sweep of bargaining than ever attempted before. The time is ripe. Last weekend's initiative in Punta del Este, Uruguay, was promising - if President Reagan can persuade Congress to go along.

docs.snippet: Economists in Washington, Mexico City and Rio de Janeiro have drafted an ambitious blueprint for renewed economic growth in Latin America that they say represents a growing consensus in the hemisphere on economic policy.   The plan calls for $20...
docs.lead_paragraph: Economists in Washington, Mexico City and Rio de Janeiro have drafted an ambitious blueprint for renewed economic growth in Latin America that they say represents a growing consensus in the hemisphere on economic policy. The plan calls for $20 billion annually in capital commitments from the United States and other industrial nations over the next several years. The amount is far more than that proposed by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d at the joint annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Seoul, South Korea, last October. Mr. Baker called for new investments of $29 billion over three years to spur growth in 15 major debtor nations, 10 of them in Latin America. The economists began formulating their plan before Mr. Baker's announcement, and many of their recommendations overlap with his. But the economists say they doubt that commercial banks are ready to answer Mr. Baker's call to provide about $20 billion of the increased financing and so have proposed a far larger role for multinational institutions such as the World Bank in the early years of their plan. Under the Baker plan, such institutions would increase loans by $9 billion over three years.

docs.snippet: PATHS TO PROGRESS Bread and Freedom in Developing Societies. By William McCord with Arline McCord. 352 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.    When world historians assess the second half of the 20th century, they are likely to focus on two...
docs.lead_paragraph: PATHS TO PROGRESS Bread and Freedom in Developing Societies. By William McCord with Arline McCord. 352 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95. When world historians assess the second half of the 20th century, they are likely to focus on two great issues - the management of the superpower rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union, and the drive of the poorer countries for economic and social development. In a very real sense, the world's future depends on the progress made on these two issues over the remainder of this century; yet surprisingly little has been written that attempts to grapple with them in a fundamental way, perhaps because the issues are so big.

headline.main: A 'FOURTH WAY' FOR THE THIRD WORLD

byline.original: By Peter D. Bell; Peter D. Bell, president of the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation, has worked more than 15 years on economic and social problems in developing societies

docs.snippet: President Reagan's offer to sell 3.85 million metric tons of subsidized American wheat to the Soviet Union expires on Tuesday, and Moscow has shown no interest.   Executives of leading grain trading companies and farm organizations said there was no...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Reagan's offer to sell 3.85 million metric tons of subsidized American wheat to the Soviet Union expires on Tuesday, and Moscow has shown no interest. Executives of leading grain trading companies and farm organizations said there was no chance a deal could be made now. Even with the subsidy, the executives said, the American price was substantially above that offered to the Russians by other nations. 'Not Going to Happen' ''The sale is not going to happen,'' said Carl Schwensen, executive vice president of the National Association of Wheat Growers, a Washington-based group representing 80,000 wheat farmers. ''But the Administration needs to try again. The Soviet Union is the world's largest wheat importer, and if our farmers are going to survive this period of low prices, we need as much trade as we can get.''

headline.main: RUSSIANS IGNORE REAGAN'S OFFER TO SELL WHEAT

byline.original: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Brazil, the third world's biggest debtor - yet one of its fastest-growing economies - predicts that commercial banks will resume lending to it voluntarily next year, Finance Minister Dilson Domingos Funaro said today.   A return to the international...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil, the third world's biggest debtor - yet one of its fastest-growing economies - predicts that commercial banks will resume lending to it voluntarily next year, Finance Minister Dilson Domingos Funaro said today. A return to the international financial markets to meet Brazil's credit needs would be the first major sign that the world debt crisis has eased, Mr. Funaro said in a breakfast interview with several reporters. ''If the largest debtor normalizes the situation, the crisis becomes much smaller,'' said the 52-year-old former business executive, who is the chief architect of the so-called Cruzado Plan. The plan, which involved sweeping economic changes, a wage-price freeze and a new currency, the cruzado, has virtually eliminated inflation without throwing Brazil into recession.

headline.main: BANK LOANS IN '87 PREDICTED BY BRAZIL

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe congratulated the United States today for the passage by Congress of sanctions on South Africa.   ''I say, well done to the people of the United States,'' Mr. Mugabe said when a reporter interrupted a news...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe congratulated the United States today for the passage by Congress of sanctions on South Africa. ''I say, well done to the people of the United States,'' Mr. Mugabe said when a reporter interrupted a news conference here with the information that the Senate had overridden President Reagan's veto of the sanctions bill. He added, ''Leaders come and leaders go, but the people live forever.'' Some of those in the room, who included African delegates as well as reporters, applauded the news. The civil rights activist Jesse Jackson, who was also present, called the veto override ''courageous and correct, the real America standing up.''

headline.main: MUGABE SAYS 'WELL DONE' ON SANCTIONS BILL PASSAGE

byline.original: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to the New York Times
